Fields.DialogueText: Look at 'em go, Captain! Don't you love watching the pilots take off?
It's certainly inspiring. Let's make sure we come through for them.
Yep! Oh, Captain... aren't you forgetting something?
What?
Captain! You promised you'd help out with my morale initiative!
Oh, yes... insulting the Morganas. Did we ever even find out if that works?
Oh, come off it! If the crew gets a kick out of it, it's a huge success!
Well, I suppose just once couldn't hurt. Where was that intercom button...?

Fields.MenuText: Attention, Morganas! Your armaments are... outdated! Very, very old. Did I mention old?
Morganas! Go fish.
(The Captain issues a string of profanity we can't possibly show here. A nearby sailor faints.)

Fields.DialogueText: Eh. We'll work on your material.
(The Captain gives her a big thumbs-up.)
Certainly got their attention...
@BATTLE
What have you got there, Lexington?
Whoa! Captain, don't sneak up on me like that!
You were sitting facing me... well, never mind.
Lexington, this is amazing! I didn't know you could draw.
It's a hobby of mine. You build the stuff I build, you need schematics.
Such as?
Weapons, machines, that kind of stuff. Did you know it's possible to make a supersonic potato gun?
Must have missed that lesson back in school. Is that... you in that picture?
Oh, yeah! Check this out - it's me as a battlecruiser!
Looks formidable. You were supposed to be one, weren't you?
Uh-huh. Till they passed that dumb treaty back in '22. I was going to have 16-inch guns! Just imagine the damage I could do with those...

Fields.MenuText: Well, you make a damn good carrier. Ask any of the pilots.
There's more to war than just how big your guns are.
We're fighting for survival. It's no use living in the past.

Fields.DialogueText: A carrier's only as good as her pilots, Cap. But I've got some keen pilots!
It's not the size, it's how you use them. But those sixteen-inchers are fun to use...
Can't help it, Captain. It's just how my imagination works.
@BATTLE
That you do. Throw them at these Morganas, would you?
Imagine taking down these Morganas, then.
Eight-inchers will have to do against these Morganas...
Lexington, how are you--
Gangway, Captain! Little Belle with big boxes coming through!
Whoa! Careful with those!
Just a minute! I'll be back in a sec!
What the hell does she think she's doing?
Okay, I'm back! How's tricks, Captain?
I should probably be asking you. What's got you in such a hurry?
Big shipment from Command! Ton of lumber, lead counterweights, few hundred feet of rope...
What do we need any of that for? You're an aircraft carrier.
Good question! Remember the other day when I was talking about my aircraft catapult?
Didn't they remove it in '35?
'36. What a dumb ol' refit that was. What if Command had your arms cut off because they couldn't think of a use for 'em?
You're being a little macabre.
Anyway! I figure if I can't have a catapult, I'll build a trebuchet! The Morganas would never see that coming.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not really sure that has military applications these days.
I suppose that's true, but not for the reasons you think.
Where, exactly, do you intend to put it?

Fields.DialogueText: That kind of thinking gets you a trebuchet projectile to the face!
It'll mess with the Morganas, and that's enough for me!
Silly! I've got a whole flight deck for that.
I'm sorry, but I can't sign off on this. It's a waste of resources.
What do you mean, "waste?"
Lexington, you're talking about using medieval siege weaponry on modern enemies. At sea. That doesn't speak for itself?
'Course it does! It says, "Lexington, make it work!"
We'll discuss this after we clear out these Morganas. Better yet, we won't.
Fine...
@BATTLE
Lexington, I'm not trying to hold you back. I'm just saying--
Come on, Captain! Imagine that Morgana from earlier taking a huge bomb to the face from a siege weapon! Don't tell me you haven't thought about it.
Until now, not really.
Think about it. What if we're out of ammo? What if the Morganas disable our guns somehow? Heck, what if they get my flight deck? My sister Saratoga did that in Fleet Problem XI, remember?
Wouldn't anything that destroyed your metal flight deck destroy a wooden trebuchet?
So we make it out of better metal! You're thinking too small, Cap. We need backup plans.

Fields.MenuText: You try justifying to Command the use of military resources on outdated weaponry.
I know you mean well, but I can't allow this. There are more important things to worry about.
We have contingencies in place for if you're disabled. That's what the light cruisers are out there for.

Fields.DialogueText: You know, I just might...
I already made all the important plans! Sometimes the unimportant ones come in handy.
Sure, but what if they aren't there?
I've said my piece. You're not building a trebuchet and that's final.
Hmph. Fine. I won't.
I'm glad we could agree on this.
Oh, me too, Captain! Me too...
@BATTLE
*YAWN* Afternoon, Cap.
Hello, Lexington. Up late drawing again?
Nah, I drew everything that was in my head. Just waiting for it to fill up again.
That's an odd way of putting it.
I like to get ideas all out at once, Captain. If they're all in front of me, I can link 'em up easier.
That makes sense. So what's got you tuckered out?
I just get bored when I'm out of ideas.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure you'll think of something. You always do.
Unfortunately, there's only so much room for innovation in a war zone.
Think of something you can't do without, and then do without it.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, but I wish it was something I could just... turn on!
So, so much room, Captain!
Hey, that's not a bad idea!
I mean, why do we come up with stuff, anyway?
That's one hell of a vague question.
Don't worry about the question, worry about the answer! Every time someone invents something, or comes up with a plan, it's to solve a problem, right?
You have a point.
Anything can be a point if you sharpen it!
I guess you have a - never mind. What were we talking about?
Judging by the Morganas nearby... blowing stuff up?
That'll do.
@BATTLE
You know what this crew needs?
Why don't you tell me?
Happy to! They need to loosen up a little.
They have down time for that.
No, I mean really loosen up! I was thinking a party sometime soon.
Let's slow down a little. When did you think you'd have the time for this?
Well, it doesn't have to happen all at once. Maybe we set up a punch bowl and music in the mess hall. Whoever's free can enjoy it, right?
I'm just a little hesitant to have them..."loosen up."
Oh, they do that already. Crew'll find a way...
Let me clarify. I'm hesitant to have them loosen up your way.
Oh, don't be like that. My way's fun and exciting!
Heh. Your way is building siege weapons and having the crew insult the Morganas. If that's how you work, you'll forgive me if I'm reluctant to see how you play.
Work is play, though! You don't have fun figuring out all of life's challenges?

Fields.MenuText: It's hard when those challenges can kill you.
I think there's a difference between "fun" and "fulfilling."
There is a time and a place for rest and relaxation, and in contested waters isn't it.

Fields.DialogueText: They can kill your enemies, too. That's the fun part!
Not if you're doing something you love. And I love a good bombardment...
I guess we'll just agree to disagree.
Look, I'll keep it small. Maybe have some quiet party games to keep the crew sharp. Please?
... It's not like your ideas haven't turned out well before. I'll tentatively approve.
Yay! You hear that, Morganas? Cap says I can play!
@BATTLE
Watch your step, Captain!
What's all this on the floor... and walls... and ceiling?
Ideas!
Concerning...?
I'm on a roll again, Captain! Battle strategies, party games, stories...
Stories? You're writing again?
Thinkin' about it! The world hasn't seen the last of Isaac Davis!
The world hasn't seen enough of USS Lexington.
Shhhh! Not so loud!
Relax. Nobody can hear us.
Still. You know how I feel about it.

Fields.MenuText: You bend the rules, but you're afraid to share when you write your own?
It's just odd to me that someone who likes attention would hide her talent.
When will you feel differently?

Fields.DialogueText: It's easier to do it in the real world when you can see how things work outside of your own head. Does that make sense?
I read somewhere that writers are shy exhibitionists. Isn't that funny?
When I change my mind. Shoo!
Can I ask which idea you're working on right now?
Well, they all kinda run together. If I come up with something that works in a story, I might try it in a fight.
About how often do you do that?
More often than you're probably comfortable knowing. I might even do it to this Morgana we're pursuing!
I guess we've been lucky so far.
I've been awesome so far!
@BATTLE
Can you sign off on this, Captain?
Sign off on what?
Requisitions from Command. I need some party favors.
Metal and munitions aren't party favors.
You haven't been to the right parties!

Fields.MenuText: What are you planning, Lexington?
I guess I've got a lot to learn about Belles.
When have you ever been to a party?

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, if this goes right, this might be the party that ends the war!
Isn't learning fun? There's something to be said for teaching, though...
Does the Boston Tea Party count? You know how Belle memories work.
I was expecting more food and music than... whatever this is. It looks more like build orders.
Think of it like a science fair! Let the crew relax, unwind, figure out how my moving parts work... it'll be educational and fun!
That's a fair point. All right, sounds good. I'm looking forward to seeing what you come up with.
I'm so excited! Did you see the invitations I sent?
Was that what the crew all got in the mail?
I spent hours making each one unique. I hope they like them!
I've always liked the attention you give the crew, Lexington. You make them feel special.
That's 'cause they are special. They wouldn't be aboard a Belle if they weren't!
Well, don't get too excited - we're getting reports of Morganas nearby.
Too late!
@BATTLE
There she is, Captain! Let me at her!
Sure. Just remember that you have not been given permission to ram the enemy, no matter how much you think you might learn about their superstructure.
I know, I know. Sensors on torpedoes first.
@BATTLE
Okay, radio crew on decorations, torpedo crew on assembly! Break!
Shouldn't they be resting after today's Morgana?
Well, seeing as the party's almost upon us, they volunteered!
Did they? Or did you volunteer them?
Don't worry, Cap, I didn't make them do anything. I'm not one of those Belles.
What do you mean "one of those Belles?"
Just that some of us are more forceful. We take the fight against the Morganas very seriously.
That's not a bad thing.
That all depends. Just be thankful I only build weapons.

Fields.MenuText: I'll let that go without comment.
"Only?"
You're just trying to help, and I appreciate that.

Fields.DialogueText: That's a good attitude... or a dangerous one. Depends on the Belle. You've got nothing to worry about from me, though!
Oh, yeah. Some Belles think that just because we're indispensable to the war effort, anything goes. I mean, they're not wrong, but...
Aww, I knew you'd understand!
I'd like to attend, but I might be busy.
It wouldn't be complete without you, Cap! You're the guest of honor!
Am I? What does that mean? What's going on at this party, anyway?
You'll see, Captain. Call it a team-building exercise...
All right, explain.
Captain, I just want you to know that I didn't break any regulations. I--
You led us all up to the flight deck and unveiled a trebuchet. Didn't I tell you not to build one?
Honest, Captain, I didn't build it!
Didn't you.
Didn't touch a single screw!
Then how did you--
Remember the invitations the crew got?
Yes, but--
Remember how I made a unique invitation for everyone?
You mean to tell me that *every single guest--*
Got detailed instructions for an itty-bitty part of my baby!
And assembled it in time for the party.
I even color-coded the invitations by what went where! Isn't it neat?

Fields.MenuText: You're obviously proud of yourself.
No siege weapons means no siege weapons. Take it down.
I'm really not sure I disagree with you.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm more proud of the crew. The more people in on a secret, the harder it is to keep!
But you haven't even seen it in action!
Does that mean you like it?
Look. There's a Morgana headed straight for us right now, and I know you can sense it. I just have one question.
Shoot.
What is the effective range of your trebuchet?
Let's give it a go! Fire!
@BATTLE
I'll be honest. I really wasn't expecting your... invention... to work.
The hardest part was fitting it on the flight deck, but once I figured that out, it was smooth sailing!
And yet we scored a direct hit on the Morgana.
Not just the enemy ship, Captain - the Morgana herself! Did you see her face?
She really wasn't so fearsome on fire.
Most of us aren't! She'll need new clothes, but it's not like she was wearing much anyway.
For a plan that amounted to "it'll be fun," it worked surprisingly well.
It's really only for Morganas that try to get in close. My guns shoot way farther than anything that uses a counterweight.
Then what's the point?
Mostly psychological. If we can beat 'em with obsolete weapons, what does that say about them?

Fields.MenuText: I thought Morganas couldn't be demoralized.
That we're better.
I still think it's nothing your guns can't accomplish.

Fields.DialogueText: Nope, but they can sure be annoyed!
By miles... by centuries, even!
It's not just about winning - it's about sending a message.
But I think the best part is that the whole crew had a hand in it. It's good to know you did something really neat.
Out of curiosity, who loaded the trebuchet?
Me!
Lexington, the payload was bigger than you are.
I'm a carrier, Cap! We're stronger than we look. Listen, there's another Morgana coming. You can watch this time!
@BATTLE
Morgana incoming!
What? Why wasn't the alarm raised?
Never mind the alarm, Captain, my senses are better! Look what she's got!
Is... is that a--
Take cover!
*BOOM*
Whew! Well, that wasn't so hard.
Unexpected, though. I'll have a merry time writing this up for Command.
We already knew that Morganas learned from our tactics and our weapons. I just didn't expect them to have trebuchets...
Or to build them so quickly. That was some fine shooting you did - I don't think her trebuchets landed a single hit.
Thanks! I don't get to use my rifle a lot. But we sure got some great fireworks out of it!
Think they'll try it again?
Oh, no way! If I know one thing about Morgana engineering, it's that they process the flaws out real quick.
So if we were to deliberately attack them with bows and arrows...
Ha! Probably not worth it. Though I'm really enjoying the thought.
@BATTLE
You're not in trouble, Lexington. I just need one question answered.
Ask away, Cap!
Do you have any other projects I need to worry about?
Oh, you don't need to worry about anything I do!
I'll try again. What else do you have planned?
That was really the big thing, Captain. I think the Morganas will think twice about getting close to us. Although...
Uh-oh.
No, don't worry, Captain! But the whole trebuchet thing got me thinking. It takes time for the Morganas to adapt to us, right?
Granted.
I'm thinking that the more basic our technology or our tactics, the quicker they figure it out.
How do you figure?
How much time passed between me unveiling my trebuchet to the Morganas unveiling theirs? Not much.
You have a point there.
But they haven't surpassed us yet. Thicker armor, bigger guns, stronger engines... but when does their biggest victory come?
At the rate they're advancing, it might not be far off.
That's what I'm thinking.
Which means it's vital that we adapt as well.
Not just adapt, Captain. Innovate! Doctrine's fine for a guideline, but we have to be willing to break the rules. Otherwise, the Morganas will learn them.
Knowing you, you've got a few tricks up your sleeve already.
Uh-huh! Let's show this Morgana a couple...
@BATTLE
You wouldn't happen to know who requisitioned the typewriter, would you?
It finally arrived! Thanks, Captain!
Needed an upgrade?
Needed a replacement. I kind of melted the old one.
I know you didn't just say "melted."
You try looking at a blank page for a whole afternoon! And with all that thermite lying around...
I wondered why it smelled like a foundry up on the flight deck.
Writer's block frustrates me. Think of it as a sacrifice to Verne.
Who?
Journey to the Center of the Earth? 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea? The Mysterious Island? Jules Verne!
That was... a strong reaction.
Of course it was! I get most of my inspiration from that man.

Fields.MenuText: There's a book out there about trebuchets on the high seas?
I suppose I lean more practical than speculative.
What would you recommend?

Fields.DialogueText: Not yet, there ain't!
They're not mutually exclusive, Captain. Sci-fi's all about solving things!
For a newcomer? Probably Journey. It's best to start early, while his style's still developing.
Does reading really help you in your work?
It helps me look at things differently. A lot of the time, the science is a metaphor, but it really makes me wonder what's possible. Problems make people creative!
Like writing with a broken typewriter.
Hey!
Here comes a Morgana. Let's solve that problem.
@BATTLE
Are we in range of Destruction?
Lemme check...
*BOOM*
Yep!
That's one way to check. Scramble the pilots. Meet me in my quarters once we're through.
Aye-aye!
@BATTLE
What's up?
It's about the trebuchet. Command is very interested in it.
Ooh! Do they want one of their own?
Not quite. In fact, they'd like you to dismantle the current one.
Okay, I was going to get around to that soon anyway.
You're not fighting me on this?
Nah, they'd probably just evolve countermeasures.
Well, Command appreciated the insight on Morgana adaptation. So I suggested they let you... experiment more.
Really? Captain, that's amazing! Thank you!
Why not? That trebuchet proved that you'll find a way to do your experiments. I may as well help you out.
You can count on me, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: I won't tell you what to do. Just come to me with ideas and I'll see what I can get out of Command.
If Command deems this not worth it, we're back to doing things by the book.
Any plans for your next weapon?

Fields.DialogueText: The hard part won't be coming up with stuff. It'll be deciding what to do!
Oh, no worries about that. I'll write us a new one!
A few. Ever heard of a railgun?
What's all this stuff in the passageway?
Whoa! Careful where you step!
What the--  Ow! Lexington!
Sorry, Cap, I should have warned you about the tripwire. I saw it in a story and just had to try it out!
While I'm impressed you were able to rig your potato gun to the tripwire, I have to say, being socked by one of those potatoes in the gut hurts like hell.
What are you doing out here?
I ran out of room on my bulkheads, so I moved my idea space into the passageway.
You really need to invest in a notebook or twelve.
It's easier to just look at something than flip through a book.

Fields.MenuText: That's a little silly. If the world worked that way, we'd run out of space to store information.
Look, there's got to be an easier way to keep your notes in one place.
Eventually you're going to run out of bulkhead space.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah, I know. But... Captain, that's it!
You know, that's not a bad idea...
I guess I just have to finish this quick. That, or... Captain, you're a genius!
What? What did I say?
You'll find out when I finish this story.
Can we take care of the Morganas first?
Let me at 'em!
@BATTLE
Here ya go, Captain!
What's this? Another story?
Yep, I wrote five thousand words last night! That's a new record for me.

Fields.MenuText: That's impressive. You'll melt another typewriter if you go any faster.
What's it about?
I'm not sure if I'll have time to get through all this.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, please. This was without any preparation or notes. I'm not even trying!
That's for me to know and you to find out!
If I can blow up some Morganas and write this, you can command me and read it!
Let's see..."The Miniature Library?" Weren't we talking about this the other day?
You told me that I needed a better way to keep my notes together. Well, this is it!
"The innermost thoughts of a nation's best and brightest were just a press of a button away!" I like the tagline.
Hopefully Amazing Stories does too! I'm thinking of submitting it.
Under your pseudonym, I notice.
People like Isaac Davis. Why not give them what they want?
They like you, too. They just don't know it yet.
That's really sweet, Captain... maybe someday. After people are familiar with my style. I don't want them to think differently of my writing because I'm a Belle.
I guess that's fair.
*ALARM*
Looks like we're being called out. I'll try and get to this after the fight.
I appreciate it, Captain.
@BATTLE
Well?
Well, what?
Did you like it? Was it good? Bad? Awesome?

Fields.MenuText: It was... interesting.
I haven't really decided yet. Still thinking.
To tell you the truth, I still haven't finished.

Fields.DialogueText: Everything is interesting! What does that mean?
Mission accomplished!
Well, you better hurry. I'm working on the next one!
The idea of a handheld device that can hold all the information you need is... intriguing. I don't know if it's plausible.
Who cares? The question is what would people do with that kind of power?
The science is a metaphor, as you said.
Yep! So you've got ultimate knowledge at your fingertips, right?
Right.
So that's that problem solved. But then what do you do with it? How do you interpret it? Isn't it easier just to entertain yourself?
I hadn't thought of it that way.
What if nobody did? Wouldn't that be terrifying?
In a sense. Not as terrifying as a Morgana. Speaking of...
Yeah, I sense her. And nah, Morganas are easy. Those you can just blow up!
@BATTLE
Captain!
Lexington?
I'm bored. Entertain me!

Fields.MenuText: You're a writer. You're never bored.
I'm your captain, not a comedian.
Should I give you something to blow up?

Fields.DialogueText: Writer's block. Sometimes I just need to step away from the paper.
Anyone can be fun in the right light! And with enough explosives...
Nah, it's no fun if I'm supposed to destroy something.
Weren't you almost done with another story?
Yeah, but I scrapped it. A guy and a girl met in a cafe, but it didn't really go anywhere.
Romance? You're branching out.
I thought about it. Then a comet struck their hometown and I stopped.
There's your story right there. Someone's living a normal life, and then something ridiculous interrupts them.
Like a Morgana attacking a cruise liner?
They say to write what you know, but don't rip it from the headlines.
Hmmm... challenge accepted!
What? What did I say?
*ALARM*
Oh, you'll see. Let's focus on the Morganas for now. Nothing inspires me more than a good tussle!
@BATTLE
Any ideas for Morgana strategies?
... Lexington?
You know, that romance I threw out got me thinking. What would you do if a comet hit you?

Fields.MenuText: Die.
Nothing I could do.
Hit back?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, besides that!
Exactly! You wouldn't be able to see it coming to react.
Definitely not... but I'll save that for another story!
I was thinking that it's not really the impact that kills you.
Yes, it is.
Okay, well, before that. You don't see it coming! That's why you're doomed.
What does that have to do with Morganas?
What if my planes were invisible?
That would certainly be useful. How in the world would you make them invisible?
Good point. But maybe I don't need invisibility... Captain, you remember Fleet Problem X?
The one where you disabled Saratoga and Langley? Of course.
Yep! Hit first and hit hard, that's what we learned from that one. We need to surprise the Morganas a little more. We need to go on the offensive!
That's a bold idea, but they're hard enough to hunt as it is. The best we can do so far is track them based on their activities.
Well, that just isn't good enough! Let's get some more spotter planes in the air, why don't we? Maybe arm them, too...
What if the world was a flight deck, is what you're suggesting.
Oh, Captain, wouldn't it be keen?
Well, we won't get the drop on this Morgana, but we'll certainly hit hard.
There's always next time! And the time after that, and the time after that...
@BATTLE
Here's an idea, Lexington...
What's on your mind, Cap?
You want to know where the Morganas are, right?
Right. Can't blow them up without!
Well, I've been reading some of that superhero story you lent me.
Ooh! Did you like it?
It got me thinking...
That's the best kind of story!
Let's say you have a hero that's unstoppable. You can't put anything in his way because he'll go around it or through it. Sort of like you.
Aww, you flatterer! There's a reason I like those stories.
So how do you stop an unstoppable force?
Deflect it somehow. Move out of the way. Distract it... Captain, that's it!

Fields.MenuText: Good, because I hadn't thought beyond that.
All we need to do is create a diversion, right?
We hire a superhero!

Fields.DialogueText: You've given me everything I need, Cap!
And I've got just the diversion in mind...
No dice, Captain, but our pilots will be the next best thing.
Now, there's this remote control plane I saw in the back of Amazing Stories...
Are you thinking what I'm thinking?
Decoys, Captain! We haven't tried those yet. How will the Morganas adapt to those? Blow 'em up faster? We'll just hit 'em when they're not looking!
I knew you'd like it.
It's sneaky! What's not to like?
Looks like the Morganas are trying some sneaking of their own. Action stations.
Oh, they won't even see me coming...
@BATTLE
So what am I looking at here?
One of my good old O2U Corsairs! I wired him up with some spare parts from the radio room. If I did this right, we should be able to fly him around with this remote control!
You learned how to do this from a toy in a magazine ad?
I just scaled everything up, Cap. How hard could that be?

Fields.MenuText: Very hard.
I'll try not to think about it.
Is that a rhetorical question?

Fields.DialogueText: Yep! That just makes it more awesome.
Just watch and learn. This'll be the best thing I've ever come up with!
Probably. Look!
With just a touch of the control stick...
It's moving!
Yes! You can do it, little guy!
And there it goes. What happens now?
Now he lets me know if there are Morganas nearby. I've practically doubled the range of my senses, and found a way to distract them!
What happens when he gets shot at?
He'll tell me which way to fly. Speak of the devil... here's one now! Get the pilots ready!
@BATTLE
That was amazing! She didn't even see us coming!
I wasn't expecting that to go so well. The Corsair even returned unharmed.
Who's a good observer plane? You are!
Command ought to love this. Good work, Lexington!
Your idea, Captain! I just put it into action.
Has the Corsair seen anything?
Not yet, Cap. Weird... I thought for sure I detected Morganas in this area.
Wait... do you see that over there? Borrow my binoculars.
Well, I'll be! Right over there in the mists... wait a minute.
What is it?
This isn't right. I would have sensed her...
Captain! Get down!
@BATTLE
What was that? I thought we could see them coming from farther away.
Never mind that, Captain! Did you see that Morgana in the mist?
No, it must have disappeared after the fight. But why would it have--
That's just it. It wasn't the real thing.
We got fooled by a decoy?
And we almost paid the price for it. We're lucky my Corsair was all we lost...

Fields.MenuText: We're going to need to explain this to Command. Tell them to switch tactics again.
We lost the Corsair? When?
How are the pilots?

Fields.DialogueText: This isn't right! Why didn't this work?
He... didn't make it back. I tried sneaking him past Delusion. I didn't expect her to catch on...
Mostly fine. The ones that aren't... they're going to be okay.
It looks like the Morganas learn faster than we give them credit for.
Command, Captain! We need to get the word out. Who knows who else got tripped up by this?
Who else?
It's not just the Morganas we fight that learn, Captain. I don't know why, but once one picks up a trick, they all do. It's how they've been getting stronger.
I'll try and get a wire to Command. Don't worry, Lexington.
Another story?
"The Shot Heard Round the Galaxy." Like the title?
Let me see...
Wait, Captain! I'm... not quite done with it yet.
When will you be? I'd like to read it.
When we hear back from Command.
I hope you're not taking it too hard. We couldn't have known how quickly the Morganas would adapt.
It just doesn't make sense, Captain... how was that mirage related to my decoy plane? And how did they pick up on it so quickly?
There's still a lot we don't know about the Morganas. It's a given that they'll surprise us.
Well, we're back to the drawing board, aren't we? I feel like we're just giving them ideas... and helping them get the drop on the other Belles.

Fields.MenuText: Only if we keep what we know to ourselves.
Don't blame yourself. Blame the Morganas. They're the ones who are keeping us in the dark.
If you run out of space on the drawing board, just use the bulkheads.

Fields.DialogueText: Publish or perish, they say in the science journals. You can't get anything done without a little peer review.
I know, Captain. I was just so sure the adaptation speed was tied to technological complexity...
Ha! I have plenty of those to go around!
... They tell me that that's another mirage. Hold on...
*BOOM*
Yep. Mirage. Action stations.
No more tricks?
All this spy stuff and Morgana business has given me an idea. Never blind with a flare what you can vaporize with a howitzer!
@BATTLE
What do your senses tell you right now?
... You're not installing a howitzer on deck.
That you know of!
Here it is!
"The Shot Heard Round the Galaxy..."
Keep reading.
By USS Lexington! Are you publishing this?
Henry Ford said that you can't build a reputation on what you're going to do. So I'm doing this.

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure? You don't have to do this if you don't want to.
So is this the last we'll see of Isaac Davis?
I'm looking forward to seeing this in Amazing Stories.

Fields.DialogueText: Sure as I'll ever be, Cap. I figure now's as good a time as any to come clean.
Maybe. I might bring him back if I try my hand at other genres.
Aww, don't be such a sweetheart!
What changed?
Don't know. People seem to be picking up on my tricks lately. Why not just step up and own 'em?
And there's a synopsis... "The starship captain was in for the fight of his life... but anything was possible with his beloved ship..."
Uh-huh...
"... Concord."
Get it? Concord?
As in the Battles of Lexington and--
Captain, would you like to go for a walk!?
As in--
With me? Around the flight deck? I know I can't leave the ship, but we could talk books and strategy, and I could cook, it'd be fun, and--
Stop. This isn't appropriate.
Captain... I'm sorry, I shouldn't have--
Not when there's a Morgana inbound. But when the smoke clears, I'd love to.
You sneaky, lying jerk!
I learned from the best.
... You did all right, Captain. You did all right.
